en_first_half: When Mr. Lorry had finished his breakfast, he went out for a stroll on the beach. The little narrow, crooked town of Dover hid itself away from the beach, and ran its head into the chalk cliffs, like a marine ostrich. The beach was a desert of heaps of sea and stones tumbling wildly about, and the sea did what it liked, and what it liked was destruction. It thundered at the town, and thundered at the cliffs, and brought the coast down, madly. The air among the
en_second_half: houses was of so strong a piscatory flavour that one might have supposed sick fish went up to be dipped in it, as sick people went down to be dipped in the sea. A little fishing was done in the port, and a quantity of strolling about by night, and looking seaward: particularly at those times when the tide made, and was near flood. Small tradesmen, who did no business whatever, sometimes unaccountably realised large fortunes, and it was remarkable that nobody in the neighbourhood could endure a lamplighter.

en_results_raw: The air among the beach huts and the fishermen's nets was filled with the cries of the gulls, and the smell of salt and seaweed hung heavy over the scene. The waves crashed against the shore, sending spray high into the air, and the sound of the surf boomed and echoed off the cliffs. Mr. Lorry walked along the beach, his eyes fixed on the sea, his mind lost in thought. He had been in Dover many times before, but today it seemed different, the sea seemed more turbulent, the wind more fierce. He quickened his pace, his boots sinking into the sand as he walked. The beach was almost deserted, only a few people were scattered about, some of them trying to salvage what they could from the wreckage that the sea had brought in. Mr. Lorry watched them for a moment, then turned his attention back to the sea. He felt a sense of unease, a feeling that something was wrong, but he couldn't quite put his finger on what it was. He walked on, the sound of the waves growing louder with every step, until he came to a small cove, partially hidden by the cliffs. The cove was a tiny, sheltered spot, a haven from the wildness of the sea. Mr. Lorry stood at the edge of the cove, looking out to sea, his eyes scanning the horizon for any sign of what was to come.

es_first_half: Terminado el almuerzo, el señor Lorry salió a dar un paseíto por la playa. No se divisaba desde ella la pequeña e irregular ciudad de Dover, excepción hecha de sus tejados que, metidos entre picachos de canteras calizas, semejaban gigantesca ostra marina. Era la playa un desierto erizado de peñascales y plagado de escollos, donde la mar hacía lo que se la antojaba, y lo que se la antojaba invariablemente era destruir. Casi de continuo rugía contra la ciudad, bramaba contra los farallones, embestía contra los peñascos que pretendían oponerse a su paso y los derribaba con estruendo. Respirábase en las casas un olor tan fuerte a pescado, que no parecía sino que los
es_second_half: habitantes de las aguas salían de éstas para curar en las casas sus enfermedades, de la misma manera que las personas enfermas suelen buscar la salud en los baños de mar. Algunos, muy pocos, se dedicaban a la pesca en aquellas aguas, y si durante el día la playa estaba siempre desierta, en cambio por la noche se veían personas que clavaban sus miradas inquietas en la inmensidad del mar. Comerciantes insignificantes a los que nunca se veía hacer un negocio, realizaban de pronto fortunas inmensas que no tenían explicación racional, y era muy de notar que nadie, por aquellos lugares, podía sufrir la presencia de una luz, de la que huían como del demonio.

El señor Lorry se sintió atraído por la playa y decidió dar un paseo más hacia el norte, donde la costa se volvía más rocosa y peligrosa. Caminó por la orilla, sintiendo el suelo bajo sus pies y escuchando el sonido de las olas que se rompían contra las rocas. De repente, vio algo que lo hizo detenerse en seco: un barco que se dirigía hacia la costa, con una bandera desgarrada y un casco dañado. El señor Lorry se sintió inmediatamente preocupado y se preguntó qué había sucedido. Se acercó un poco más para ver mejor y vio que el barco estaba a punto de chocar contra un peñascal. El señor Lorry se sintió a punto de gritar, pero no pudo hacer nada para evitar el desastre. El barco se estrelló contra la roca con un estruendo ensordecedor, y el señor Lorry se quedó paralizado, esperando a ver qué sucedería a continuación. La multitud que se había reunido en la playa se puso a gritar y a correr hacia el lugar del accidente, y el señor Lorry se unió a ellos, sintiendo un sentimiento de curiosidad y preocupación. Al llegar al lugar, vio que el barco estaba en pedazos, y los marineros estaban intentando ayudar a los supervivientes a salir del agua. El señor Lorry se unió a la multitud que se había reunido en la orilla, y vio a un hombre que parecía estar gravemente herido. Se acercó a él y le preguntó si estaba bien, pero el hombre no respondió. El señor Lorry se sintió conmovido por la escena y decidió ayudar a los marineros a cuidar a los heridos. Mientras tanto, la multitud se puso a discutir sobre lo que había sucedido, y algunos decían que el barco había sido atacado por piratas, mientras que otros decían que había sido un accidente. El señor Lorry no sabía qué creer, pero estaba seguro de que había sido un desastre terrible. La policía y los bomberos llegaron pronto al lugar, y se pusieron a trabajar para ayudar a los heridos y a limpiar el lugar. El señor Lorry se quedó un rato más para asegurarse de que todo estuviera en orden, y luego se despidió de los marineros y se fue a su casa, sintiendo un sentimiento de tristeza y preocupación por lo sucedido. Al llegar a su casa, se sentó en su sillón favorito y se quedó pensando en lo que había visto. Se preguntó qué había sucedido realmente con el barco y quién había estado a bordo. Mientras tanto, la noticia del accidente se extendió rápidamente por la ciudad, y la gente comenzó a hablar sobre lo que había sucedido. Algunos decían que había sido un acto de sabotaje, mientras que otros decían que había sido un accidente. El señor Lorry no sabía qué creer, pero estaba seguro de que había sido un desastre terrible. La policía y los investigadores se pusieron a trabajar para determinar lo que había sucedido, y el señor Lorry se sintió aliviado de que estuvieran investigando el caso. Sin embargo, no podía quitarse de la cabeza la imagen del barco estrellado contra la roca y de los marineros intentando ayudar a los heridos. Se sintió conmovido por la escena y se preguntó qué había sido lo que había llevado a ese desastre. en_first_half: Madame Defarge, his wife, sat in the shop behind the counter as he came in. Madame Defarge was a stout woman of about his own age, with a watchful eye that seldom seemed to look at anything, a large hand heavily ringed, a steady face, strong features, and great composure of manner. There was a character about Madame Defarge, from which one might have predicated that she did not often make mistakes against herself in any of the reckonings over which she presided. Madame Defarge being sensitive to cold, was wrapped in fur, and had a quantity of bright shawl twined about her head,
en_second_half: though not to the concealment of her large earrings. Her knitting was before her, but she had laid it down to pick her teeth with a toothpick. Thus engaged, with her right elbow supported by her left hand, Madame Defarge said nothing when her lord came in, but coughed just one grain of cough. This, in combination with the lifting of her darkly defined eyebrows over her toothpick by the breadth of a line, suggested to her husband that he would do well to look round the shop among the customers, for any new customer who had dropped in while he stepped over the way.
en_results: Her eyes, however, were not the only feature of Madame Defarge that caught the attention of the man as he entered the shop. en_results_raw: Her eyes, however, were not the only feature of Madame Defarge that caught the attention of the man as he entered the shop. Her hands, though large and heavily ringed, were deft and quick in their movements as she worked, measuring out threads and yarns with a precision that suggested a mind accustomed to exacting standards. The air in the shop was thick with the smell of wool and dye, and the soft hum of a loom could be heard in the back room, where a young girl was busy at work. Madame Defarge's husband, Monsieur Defarge, was nowhere to be seen, but a small, wiry man with a pointed beard and a keen eye was standing behind the counter, watching the newcomer with a mixture of curiosity and suspicion. The man, who had been a regular customer at the shop for some time, felt a sense of unease as he approached the counter, as if he was being sized up and weighed in the balance. Madame Defarge, however, seemed entirely uninterested in him, her gaze fixed on the threads and yarns in front of her, her expression a mask of calm and composure. The man cleared his throat to announce his presence, and Madame Defarge looked up, her eyes narrowing slightly as she took in his face. "What can I do for you, Monsieur...?" she asked, her voice low and smooth, but with a hint of a question in it. The man hesitated, unsure of how to respond, and Madame Defarge's eyes seemed to bore into his very soul, as if searching for something. The air in the shop seemed to grow colder, and the man felt a shiver run down his spine as he tried to gather his thoughts and respond to Madame Defarge's question.

es_first_half: La señora Defarge, esposa del tabernero en cuestión, estaba sentada detrás del mostrador cuando aquél entró en el establecimiento. Era mujer de constitución robusta, aproximadamente de la edad misma que su marido, de ojos vigilantes, aunque muy contadas veces parecía mirar a ningún objeto determinado, grandes manos cubiertas de sortijas, cara de líneas enérgicas, expresión reservada y aire de perfecta compostura. Una de las características de la señora Defarge consistía en no sufrir nunca equivocaciones que redundasen en perjuicio de sus intereses en ninguna de las operaciones del establecimiento. Extremadamente sensible al frío, iba envuelta en pieles y abrigaba su cabeza con un chal de colores chillones que la cubría por completo, bien que dejando a la vista los grandes
es_second_half: pendientes que adornaban sus orejas. Tenía frente a sí su calceta, pero la había dejado sobre el mostrador para consagrar algunos minutos a la limpieza de su dentadura, lo que estaba haciendo con un mondadientes. Absorta en su ocupación, con el codo derecho apoyado sobre la mano izquierda, nada dijo la señora Defarge cuando su marido entró en el establecimiento, pero dejó oir una tosecita apenas perceptible. La tosecita, combinada con un ligero enarcamiento de sus cejas, negras como el ala del cuervo y perfectamente arqueadas, dió a entender a su marido la conveniencia de dar un vistazo a los clientes, entre los cuales acaso encontrase alguno nuevo que había llegado a la taberna mientras se encontraba en la calle.

You are not bound to give it in a way that will compromise your own safety, or the safety of those who are dear to you, nor are you bound to give it in a way that will bring you personal gain, or advantage. You are bound to give it with the utmost sincerity, and with the utmost candour, and you are bound to give it in a way that will be consistent with your own honour, and your own conscience. And if you do give it in this way, I promise you that you will be treated with the utmost respect, and with the utmost kindness, and that you will be protected from any harm, or any injury, that may come to you as a result of your giving it. But if you do not give it in this way, I must tell you that you will be doing a great wrong, and that you will be doing a great injustice, and that you will be bringing shame and dishonour upon yourself, and upon your family, and upon your friends. So I ask you, Miss Manette, to give the evidence that you have, and to give it freely, and to give it sincerely, and to give it in the way that you think will best serve the truth, and the interests of justice. Will you do this, Miss Manette?

en_results: of a company is being run by a group of people who are not always in agreement, it would be a lot more complicated
en_results_raw: of a company is being run by a group of people who are not always in agreement, it would be a lot more complicated than it already is. The constant juggling of ideas, the weighing of pros and cons, the endless debates over the best course of action - it's a delicate balancing act that requires a great deal of skill and diplomacy. Sometimes, it feels like a game of chess, where each player is trying to outmaneuver the others, but without checkmating the entire operation in the process. The stakes are high, and the pressure is intense, but that's what makes it so thrilling for those who are passionate about the business. They thrive on the challenge, the uncertainty, and the constant need to adapt and evolve. It's a world where creativity and logic collide, where intuition and analysis are constantly at odds, and where the outcome is never certain until the very end. And yet, it's in this very uncertainty that the seeds of innovation are sown, and the most brilliant ideas are born.

en_second_half: from the largest object to the least; the arrangement of colours, the elegant variety and contrast obtained by thrift in trifles, by delicate hands, clear eyes, and good sense; were at once so pleasant in themselves, and so expressive of their originator, that, as Mr. Lorry stood looking about him, the very chairs and tables seemed to ask him, with something of that peculiar expression which he knew so well by this time, whether he approved?

en_results_raw: The rooms were a perfect reflection of her character, a blend of elegance and thrift, with a dash of whimsy that made them feel truly unique. Every item, no matter how small or insignificant it may have seemed, had been carefully chosen to contribute to the overall atmosphere of warmth and welcome that pervaded the space. The walls, painted a soft, creamy color, were adorned with a few choice pieces of artwork, each one telling a story or evoking a memory that was dear to her heart. The furniture, though plain, was polished to a high shine, and the few ornaments that dotted the surfaces sparkled with a quiet beauty that was all the more striking for its understatement. In every corner, there was a sense of comfort and contentment, a feeling that this was a place where one could truly be oneself, without fear of judgment or criticism. And yet, despite the air of simplicity that pervaded the rooms, there was a sense of depth and complexity, a sense that there was more to this young woman than met the eye. She was a true product of her country of birth, with all its attendant virtues and vices, and her home was a reflection of that.

es_first_half: Aunque nada aprendió la hija del doctor en su patria de origen, es lo cierto que ésta la inició en aquella habilidad rara que consiste en hacer mucho con medios escasos, lo que constituía una de sus características más preciosas y agradables. Modesto y sencillo era el mobiliario de las habitaciones de la casa, y esto no obstante, algunas chucherías, que no tenían más valor real que el gusto exquisito con que estaban colocadas, daban a aquéllas un efecto delicioso.
es_second_half: La disposición de cuanto en la casa había, comenzando por el mueble más grande y acabando por el objeto más insignificante, la combinación de colores, y el contraste obtenido merced a nonadas por manos delicadas, ojos de mirada clara y sentidos de gusto irreprochable, ofrecían un conjunto tan agradable en sí y retrataban tan gráficamente a su autora, que no parecía sino que con mudo pero elocuente lenguaje preguntaban al señor Lorry, mientras extasiado los contemplaba, si merecían su aprobación.
es_results: La casa, que se encontraba en un barrio tranquilo de la ciudad, era un refugio acogedor para la joven, que había crecido en un entorno más austero. La hija del doctor, cuyo nombre era Sofía, había heredado la capacidad de su padre para crear belleza a partir de lo cotidiano, y su habitación era un ejemplo perfecto de esto. A pesar de que el mobiliario era modesto, cada objeto que había en la habitación había sido cuidadosamente seleccionado y colocado para crear un ambiente acogedor y agradable.
es_results_raw: La casa, que se encontraba en un barrio tranquilo de la ciudad, era un refugio acogedor para la joven, que había crecido en un entorno más austero. La hija del doctor, cuyo nombre era Sofía, había heredado la capacidad de su padre para crear belleza a partir de lo cotidiano, y su habitación era un ejemplo perfecto de esto. A pesar de que el mobiliario era modesto, cada objeto que había en la habitación había sido cuidadosamente seleccionado y colocado para crear un ambiente acogedor y agradable. Un viejo reloj de péndulo colgado en la pared, un cuadro de flores en un rincón, y un sofá tapizado de terciopelo rojo en un rincón, daban a la habitación un toque de elegancia y sofisticación. La habitación de Sofía era un refugio para ella, un lugar donde podía escapar del mundo exterior y sumergirse en sus propios pensamientos y sueños. A medida que crecía, Sofía se convirtió en una joven inteligente y creativa, que se inspiraba en la belleza y la simplicidad de su entorno para crear su propia obra de arte. Su padre, el doctor, la alentaba en su creatividad, y juntos exploraban la ciudad en busca de inspiración y nuevas ideas. La relación entre Sofía y su padre era muy estrecha, y su casa era un lugar donde la familia se reunía para compartir momentos juntos y crear recuerdos que durarían toda la vida.

en_second_half: it was not to be expected that anybody should be, under any circumstances. But it really is doubly and trebly hard to have crowds and multitudes of people turning up after him (I could have forgiven him), to take Ladybird’s affections away from me.”

Still, I have faith in her, and I know that she will find a way to navigate the challenges that lie ahead, even if it means sacrificing her own happiness in the process. en_second_half: not in a character that gives facilities for seeing much of it. They told me a curious thing when I was there.”
en_results: under the pressure of a great and terrible necessity, I have walked the streets of Paris, and seen the worst of
en_results_raw: under the pressure of a great and terrible necessity, I have walked the streets of Paris, and seen the worst of human nature, but never have I seen anything to compare with the horrors that I witnessed in that place, the night that I saw the guillotine in action, the night that I saw the blood of the innocent flowing like a river, the night that I saw the faces of the people, their eyes filled with a madness that I had never seen before, a madness that seemed to consume them, body and soul, and I knew in that moment that I was in the presence of something truly evil, something that would haunt me for the rest of my days, and yet, I was drawn to it, fascinated by the sheer brutality of it all, the way that the crowd seemed to feed on the fear and the blood, and I knew that I had to get out of there, to escape the darkness that was consuming me, but I was trapped, trapped by my own curiosity, trapped by the desire to see more, to know more, and so I stayed, I stayed and watched, and I saw things that no man should ever have to see, things that would haunt me for the rest of my days, things that would change me forever, things that would make me question everything I thought I knew about humanity, and about myself.

The proprietor, a stout man with a bushy beard, polished a mug with a dirty apron, his eyes darting nervously towards the door, as if expecting the arrival of some long-awaited guest. The fire crackled and spat, casting flickering shadows on the walls, and the air was thick with the smell of smoke and stale ale. Outside, the city was alive with the sounds of revelry and music, but in this dingy wine-shop, all was quiet and still, except for the soft murmur of hushed conversations and the occasional clinking of glasses. The spies, whoever they were, seemed to have vanished into thin air, leaving behind only the faintest whisper of their presence, a hint of a secret that only the wind knew.

es_results_raw: apuestas de poca monta, los dados callaban en sus cajas y los dados de azar se quedaban sin apostantes. El dueño de la taberna, un hombre de rostro cansado y ojos que parecían haber visto demasiado, se sentaba detrás del mostrador, mirando con desgana a los pocos clientes que se atrevían a entrar. La puerta de la taberna estaba abierta de par en par, permitiendo que el viento frío de la noche entrara y se llevara consigo el poco calor que quedaba en el local. El fuego de la chimenea se redujo a un simple rescoldo, y el humo se elevaba hacia el techo, formando una niebla espesa que cubría la habitación. En el rincón más oscuro de la taberna, un hombre sentado en una silla, con la cabeza apoyada en la mano, parecía sumido en sus pensamientos, sin prestar atención a la escena que se desarrollaba a su alrededor. Su rostro era el de un hombre cansado, con ojeras oscuras y una mirada perdida. Su ropa era pobre y desgastada, y su presencia parecía ser un recordatorio de que, en ese momento, la taberna no era un lugar de diversión, sino un lugar de refugio para aquellos que no tenían otro lugar adónde ir. El dueño de la taberna, notando la presencia del hombre, se levantó del mostrador y se acercó a él, con una mirada de curiosidad en los ojos. "¿Qué te trae por aquí?", preguntó con una voz que era a la vez amable y desconfiada. El hombre levantó la cabeza y miró al dueño, con una mirada que parecía decir "¿qué importa?", pero que en realidad decía mucho más. El dueño de la taberna se sentó en la silla al lado del hombre, y comenzó a hablar con él, tratando de sacarle de su letargo. Pero el hombre no parecía dispuesto a hablar, y se limitaba a mirar al fuego, con una expresión que parecía decir "no tengo nada que decir". El dueño de la taberna se quedó callado, observando al hombre con una mirada de curiosidad, tratando de descubrir qué lo había llevado a ese lugar, y qué lo había llevado a estar en ese estado. La noche pasaba, y la taberna se quedaba cada vez más vacía, pero el dueño de la taberna no se movió de su silla, esperando a que el hombre hablara, a que se decidiera a contar su historia. Pero el hombre seguía callado, sumido en sus pensamientos, y el dueño de la taberna se quedó allí, sentado en la oscuridad, esperando a que algo sucediera.

en_results_raw: The figure was shrouded in a hooded cloak, its face obscured by the shadows. It seemed to be watching me with an unblinking gaze, its presence both captivating and unnerving. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I tried to make out any defining features, but it remained a mystery, a silent observer in the darkness. The wind rustled through the trees, causing the branches to creak and sway, but the figure remained steadfast, a constant presence that seemed to be waiting for something. Or someone. I strained my eyes, trying to pierce the veil of uncertainty, but it was no use. The figure remained an enigma, a riddle that I was powerless to solve. And yet, I felt drawn to it, a morbid fascination that I couldn't shake. It was as if I was being pulled into a world beyond my own, a world where the laws of reality no longer applied. I took a step forward, my heart pounding in my chest, and that was when I saw it. A faint smile played on the figure's lips, a subtle curve that seemed to hint at a secret, a secret that only it knew. I felt a chill run down my spine as I realized that I was not alone, that there was something else out there, watching me, waiting for me. And I knew that I had to find out what it was.

en_results_raw: <output>The window was open, and the Doctor sat in his armchair, his eyes fixed on the fire, which was burning low. The room was quiet, except for the occasional crackle of the flames, and the soft ticking of the clock on the mantlepiece. Mr. Lorry noticed that the Doctor's face was pale and drawn, and his eyes seemed sunken, as if he had not slept for some time. He sat down in the chair opposite the Doctor, and cleared his throat to speak, but the Doctor did not look up. "How is she?" Mr. Lorry asked, his voice low and gentle. The Doctor slowly turned his head, and looked at Mr. Lorry with a faint glimmer of recognition in his eyes. "She is...stable," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. "But she has been through a great ordeal, and it will take time for her to recover." Mr. Lorry nodded, his face set in a determined expression. "I will stay with her," he said. "I will not leave her side until she is well again." The Doctor nodded, a small smile on his lips. "I knew I could count on you, Mr. Lorry," he said. "You have always been a true friend to her." Mr. Lorry stood up, and walked over to the window, looking out into the darkness. The night was still and quiet, the only sound the distant hooting of an owl. He stood there for a moment, lost in thought, before turning back to the Doctor. "What happened to her?" he asked, his voice firm. The Doctor sighed, and rubbed his temples. "It is a long story," he said. "But I will tell you, if you wish to know." Mr. Lorry nodded, his eyes fixed intently on the Doctor's face. "I want to know," he said. The Doctor took a deep breath, and began to speak, his voice low and measured. "It started several days ago," he said. "She had been acting strangely, becoming more and more withdrawn. I thought it was just her usual melancholy, but then she began to experience...visions." Mr. Lorry's eyes widened in surprise. "Visions?" he repeated. The Doctor nodded. "Yes, visions of the past. She would see things that had happened years ago, and she would become convinced that they were happening again. I tried to reassure her, but she became more and more agitated. And then, last night, she had a...a fit." Mr. Lorry's face was set in a grim expression. "A fit?" he repeated. The Doctor nodded. "Yes, a fit of some kind. I don't know what it was, but it was like nothing I have ever seen before. She became violent, and had to be restrained. I was afraid for her safety, and for the safety of those around her." Mr. Lorry's eyes were filled with concern. "Is she going to be all right?" he asked. The Doctor hesitated, unsure of how to answer. "I don't know," he said finally. "I truly don't know. en_results_raw: <output>The cries of the prisoners, a cacophony of despair and desperation, echoed through the air as they clung to the debris that had once been their home, their voices hoarse from screaming for help that never came. The sea, a relentless and unforgiving force, continued to rise, its waves crashing against the remnants of the prison, sending shards of wood and twisted metal flying in all directions. The officers, their faces etched with fear, struggled to keep their footing as the water surged around them, threatening to sweep them away. Amidst the chaos, a figure emerged from the depths of the prison, a young woman with a look of determination etched on her face, her eyes fixed on the horizon as she fought to stay afloat. She was one of the lucky ones, for she had managed to escape the initial wave, but she knew that her ordeal was far from over. The sea was a cruel mistress, and she would not be easily tamed. As she paddled through the water, she spotted a piece of debris, a wooden plank, half-submerged in the waves. With a surge of hope, she reached out and grabbed hold of it, using all her strength to pull herself onto its surface. For a moment, she lay there, exhausted, her chest heaving with exertion, as she gazed out at the sea, her mind reeling with the thought of what lay ahead. The cries of the other prisoners still echoed in her ears, a haunting reminder of the lives lost, and the lives that still hung in the balance. She knew she had to keep moving, to find a way to safety, to escape the clutches of the sea and the prison that had once held her captive. But as she looked around, she realized that she was not alone. A figure, a man, was clinging to a nearby piece of debris, his eyes fixed on her with a look of desperation. She hesitated for a moment, unsure of what to do, but something about his gaze struck a chord within her. She reached out a hand, and he grasped it, pulling himself onto the plank beside her. Together, they rode the waves, their bodies battered and bruised, but their spirits unbroken. As the sun began to set, casting a golden glow over the wreckage, they spotted a glimmer of hope on the horizon - a ship, its sails billowing in the wind, its crew scanning the water for survivors. With renewed energy, they paddled towards it, their hearts filled with a sense of determination and hope. They knew that they still had a long way to go, but they were no longer alone, and that gave them the strength to carry on. As they drew closer to the ship, they could see the faces of the crew, their expressions a mix of concern and relief. The woman and the man, their names lost to the annals of time, were among the lucky ones, rescued from the jaws of death and given a second chance at life. But as they were pulled aboard, they knew that their ordeal was far from over. The memories of the prison and the sea would haunt them for the rest of their days, a constant reminder of the fragility of life and the power of the human spirit. They would never forget the cries of the prisoners, the sound of the sea, and the feeling of being adrift in a world that seemed determined to destroy them. But they would also never forget the sense of hope that had sustained them, the knowledge that even in the darkest of times, there is always a glimmer of light, a chance for redemption and a new beginning. And as they looked out at the sea, now a calm and peaceful expanse, they knew that they would carry that hope with them, a beacon of light in the darkness, a reminder of the strength that lay within them. The sea had taken much from them, but it had also given them a gift - the gift of life, and the knowledge that they were capable of overcoming even the most daunting of challenges. And as they sailed away from the wreckage, they knew that they would never be the same again, that they had been forever changed by their experience, and that they would carry the lessons of the sea with them for the rest of their lives. The cries of the prisoners still echoed in their minds, a haunting reminder of the past, but they knew that they had been given a second chance, a chance to start anew, to rebuild and to rediscover themselves. And as they sailed into the sunset, they knew that they would face the future with courage and determination, their hearts filled with hope and their spirits unbroken. en_first_half: Seven prisoners released, seven gory heads on pikes, the keys of the accursed fortress of the eight strong towers, some discovered letters and other memorials of prisoners of old time, long dead of broken hearts,—such, and such—like, the loudly echoing footsteps of Saint Antoine escort through the Paris streets in mid-July, one thousand

The people, in their fervor, had stormed the Bastille, that infamous prison, and now the city was alive with the spirit of liberty and freedom. The sound of drums and trumpets filled the air as the National Guard marched through the streets, their tricolor flags waving high. The smell of gunpowder and smoke hung heavy over the city, a reminder of the bloodshed and violence that had brought about this momentous day. As the crowd surged forward, a young woman, her hair disheveled and her eyes wild with excitement, pushed her way to the front of the procession. She was a member of the sans-culottes, a radical faction of the Revolution, and she reveled in the chaos and anarchy that surrounded her. The sound of the drums grew louder, and the crowd began to chant, their voices rising in a crescendo of "Vive la Révolution!" as they marched towards the Hôtel de Ville, the seat of the city's government. The fate of France hung in the balance, and the people were determined to see their revolution through to its conclusion.

Los prisioneros
es_results_raw: <output>que de tal suceso, que los que lo presenciaron, con el alma llena de espanto y el corazón lleno de dolor, no puedan olvidarlo jamás. La multitud que se había congregado en las calles para presenciar el triunfo de la Revolución, se vio sorprendida por la visión de la sangre y la muerte, y muchos de ellos se retiraron con la cara cubierta con el pañuelo, horrorizados por lo que habían visto. Los prisioneros libertados, con sus ropas desgarradas y sus ojos vacíos, caminaban con la cabeza gacha, sin poder creer que hubieran logrado escapar de la muerte. Los soldados que los escoltaban, con sus uniformes limpios y sus armas relucientes, parecían orgullosos de su victoria, pero no podían ocultar la expresión de tristeza que se reflejaba en sus rostros. La procesión avanzaba lentamente por las calles empedradas, con la multitud que la seguía en silencio, como si estuvieran presenciando un funeral. Algunos de los espectadores se acercaron a los prisioneros, intentando hablar con ellos, pero estos no respondían, como si estuvieran en un estado de shock. La escena era tan conmocionante que muchos de los presentes se preguntaban si lo que estaban viendo era real o si era solo una pesadilla. La procesión continuó avanzando, hasta que llegó a la Plaza de la Revolución, donde se encontraba la guillotina, el instrumento de la muerte que había sido el símbolo de la Revolución Francesa. Allí, los prisioneros fueron sometidos a un interrogatorio, para saber si eran verdaderos patriotas o si eran espías que habían sido capturados por error. La multitud esperaba con ansias el resultado, sabiendo que la suerte de los prisioneros dependía de la respuesta que dieran. Mientras tanto, en la sombra, un hombre observaba la escena con una mirada de descontento, sabiendo que la Revolución estaba comenzando a corromperse y que la sangre y la muerte estaban a punto de convertirse en el símbolo de la libertad. Su nombre era Maximilien Robespierre, y era uno de los líderes de la Revolución, pero estaba empezando a darse cuenta de que la Revolución que habían luchado por crear, estaba comenzando a destruirse a sí misma. La historia de la Revolución Francesa estaba a punto de tomar un giro oscuro, y nadie sabía qué consecuencias tendría. Similarly, during two or three hours of drawl, and the winnowing of many bushels of words, Madame Defarge’s frequent glances at the guillotine, which stood in the centre of the square, seemed to grow more and more triumphant, as if she saw in it a symbol of the impending doom that was to befall the hated aristocracy. The crowd, caught up in the fervour of the moment, began to chant slogans and sing revolutionary songs, their voices echoing off the stone buildings and sending shivers down the spines of the few who dared to oppose them. As the sun began to set, casting long shadows across the square, Madame Defarge's eyes gleamed with an unholy light, her face a mask of fanaticism, as she continued to weave her web of hatred and revenge, her every word and gesture fueling the flames of revolution that threatened to consume them all. The air was thick with tension, heavy with the weight of unspoken threats and unfulfilled promises, as the crowd waited with bated breath for the next move in the game of revolution, and Madame Defarge, the self-appointed mistress of the guillotine, stood at its centre, her power and influence growing with every passing moment.

La multitud se hizo silencio, esperando a que la señora Defarge comenzara a hablar, y en ese momento, el juez levantó la mano para pedir silencio. La señora Defarge se detuvo en el umbral de la puerta del estrado, y con una voz que resonó en toda la sala, comenzó a hablar. "Señor juez", dijo, "he venido aquí hoy para testificar en contra de Charles Darnay, y para demostrar que es culpable de los cargos que se le imputan". La multitud se estremeció al escuchar las palabras de la señora Defarge, y el juez se inclinó hacia adelante, interesado en escuchar lo que ella tenía que decir. La señora Defarge se detuvo un momento, y luego continuó hablando, su voz llena de pasión y convicción. "Charles Darnay es un traidor", dijo, "un hombre que ha vendido su patria y su honor por una fortuna y un título". en_results_raw: The door was flung open, and a man in a nightcap, with a large bunch of keys at his waist, stood in the doorway, staring out into the darkness. "What's the matter?" he exclaimed, as the horse, still snorting and trembling, was led into the courtyard. The rider, a young woman with a determined look on her face, leapt from the saddle and approached Monsieur Gabelle, who was now standing in the doorway, his eyes wide with alarm. "It's the revolution," she said, her voice low and urgent. "The people are rising, and I must get to the chateau at once." Monsieur Gabelle's face went pale, and he hesitated for a moment before nodding and stepping aside to let her pass. As she rode off into the night, the sound of distant drums and shouting grew louder, and the village was plunged into chaos.

The sky above was a deep, foreboding grey, with clouds that seemed to twist and writhe like living serpents, their dark bellies heavy with the promise of destruction. As the waters continued their relentless ascent, the air grew thick with the stench of salt and smoke, a noxious miasma that choked the lungs and made it hard to breathe. The very fabric of the world seemed to be unraveling, torn asunder by the fury of the elements, leaving only chaos and despair in its wake.

es_second_half: leal a él y a su familia, fué para Darnay a manera de latigazo recibido en pleno rostro. La vergüenza se le subió a la cara con fuerza tal, que mientras caminaba al azar sin saber qué resolución adoptar, ni a mirar a los transeuntes se atrevía.

es_results_raw: amado y leal servidor, se convirtió en una realidad inminente y amenazante. La noticia de que su nombre figuraba en la lista de los sospechosos de traición, difundida por el gobierno revolucionario, había sido confirmada por un amigo de confianza que había logrado escapar de París. Darnay, que siempre había sido un hombre de gran calma y serenidad, se sintió invadido por un sentimiento de desesperanza y miedo, que le hacía temblar las manos y le nublaba la mente. La idea de ser arrestado y condenado a muerte por un delito que no había cometido, era demasiado terrible de soportar. Se preguntaba cómo había llegado a tal situación y qué podía hacer para evitarla. Mientras tanto, su esposa Lucie, que siempre había sido su fuente de consuelo y apoyo, se encontraba en una situación aún más precaria, ya que su padre, el anciano Monsieur Defarge, había sido arrestado por sus actividades revolucionarias y se encontraba en la cárcel. La situación parecía cada vez más desesperada y Darnay se preguntaba si alguna vez podría encontrar la forma de escapar de la trampa en la que se había visto envuelto.

en_first_half: He knew very well, that in his horror of the deed which had culminated the bad deeds and bad reputation of the old family house, in his resentful suspicions of his uncle, and in the aversion with which his conscience regarded the crumbling fabric that he was supposed to uphold, he had acted imperfectly. He knew
en_second_half: very well, that in his love for Lucie, his renunciation of his social place, though by no means new to his own mind, had been hurried and incomplete. He knew that he ought to have systematically worked it out and supervised it, and that he had meant to do it, and that it had never been done.
en_results: that he had acted imperfectly, driven by a mix of emotions that he could hardly understand himself. His mind was a jumble of guilt, anger, and a deep-seated need for justice, which he had tried to justify with the noble intention of clearing his family's name. But now, as he stood amidst the
en_results_raw: that he had acted imperfectly, driven by a mix of emotions that he could hardly understand himself. His mind was a jumble of guilt, anger, and a deep-seated need for justice, which he had tried to justify with the noble intention of clearing his family's name. But now, as he stood amidst the ruins of the old mansion, he couldn't shake off the feeling that he had only managed to destroy the very thing he had set out to protect. The weight of his actions bore down on him, and he felt a sense of despair wash over him, threatening to consume him whole. He thought of his uncle, of the man he had once looked up to, and the pain of his betrayal cut deep. He wondered if he had been blinded by his own prejudices, if he had let his emotions cloud his judgment, and if he had ultimately done more harm than good. The questions swirled in his mind, taunting him, as he stood there, lost and alone in the darkness.

es_first_half: Sabía muy bien que, arrastrado por el horror de la hazaña que puso digno remate a las malas acciones y a la pésima reputación de su rancia familia, impulsado por las sospechas que su tío le inspirara y por la aversión con que su conciencia miraba la fábrica ruinosa que, según los de su casta, estaba en el deber de sostener y robustecer,
es_second_half: había obrado de una manera imperfecta. Sabía muy bien que al ceder al amor que profesaba a Lucía, al renunciar el puesto que en sociedad le correspondía ocupar, se había precipitado, había procedido con reprensible ligereza. Sabía muy bien que su resolución debió llevarla a la práctica personalmente, como sabía que tuvo intención de hacerlo así, y que, sin embargo, no lo hizo.
es_results: decidió abandonar la fábrica y dejar que su tío y sus parientes se encargaran de su decadencia, pero no pudo resistir la tentación de visitarla una última vez, para ver con sus propios ojos el estado en que se encontraba, y para recordar a su conciencia la responsabilidad que había rechazado. Al llegar a la fábrica, se sintió abrumado por la desolación que lo rodeaba, el olor a
es_results_raw: decidió abandonar la fábrica y dejar que su tío y sus parientes se encargaran de su decadencia, pero no pudo resistir la tentación de visitarla una última vez, para ver con sus propios ojos el estado en que se encontraba, y para recordar a su conciencia la responsabilidad que había rechazado. Al llegar a la fábrica, se sintió abrumado por la desolación que lo rodeaba, el olor a humo y a mugre lo envolvía, y el silencio era solo interrumpido por el canto de los pájaros que habían hecho de la fábrica su hogar. La maquinaria oxidada y el polvo que cubría todo lo que había sido alguna vez productivo, le recordaban a la decadencia de su propia familia, y se preguntaba si había tomado la decisión correcta al dejar que todo esto se desmoronara. Mientras caminaba por los pasillos vacíos, se encontró con un viejo diario que había sido dejado en una mesa de trabajo, y al abrirlo, se encontró con una nota escrita a mano que decía: "No te rindas, hay esperanza en la oscuridad". La nota parecía ser de su padre, y le dio fuerzas para seguir adelante, para encontrar una forma de revivir la fábrica y restaurar la reputación de su familia. Pero, ¿era demasiado tarde? ¿Había perdido la oportunidad de hacerlo? Solo el tiempo lo diría.

Mientras tanto, la escolta y el escoltado habían desaparecido en el cuerpo de guardia, y los viajeros a caballo seguían esperando a que les permitieran pasar. El sol comenzaba a ponerse en el horizonte, y el aire se estaba volviendo cada vez más frío y más húmedo. Carlos Darnay se estremeció y se ajustó el capote que llevaba sobre los hombros, y se preguntó cuánto tiempo más tendrían que esperar. De repente, un oficial de la guardia salió del cuerpo de guardia y se acercó a los viajeros a caballo, y les preguntó quiénes eran y qué venían a hacer en la ciudad. Carlos Darnay se presentó y explicó su situación, y el oficial lo miró con curiosidad y le preguntó si sabía algo de un tal Lucien Defarge, un patriota que había estado en París durante la Revolución. Carlos Darnay se sorprendió al oír el nombre, y le preguntó al oficial qué quería saber de él. El oficial le explicó que Defarge había sido un hombre muy peligroso, que había estado involucrado en muchos asesinatos y que había sido uno de los principales instigadores de la Revolución. Carlos Darnay se sintió asustado y le preguntó al oficial si creía que Defarge estaba en la ciudad. El oficial le dijo que no lo sabía, pero que había oído rumores de que estaba escondido en algún lugar de la ciudad, y que estaba buscando a alguien que lo ayudara a encontrarlo. Carlos Darnay se sintió aterrorizado y le preguntó al oficial qué podía hacer para evitar que lo encontraran. El oficial le dijo que no podía hacer nada, pero que podía ofrecerle su protección si quería quedarse en la ciudad. Carlos Darnay se sintió agradecido y aceptó la oferta del oficial, y se quedó en la ciudad con la escolta del oficial. Mientras tanto, la noche comenzaba a caer sobre la ciudad, y Carlos Darnay se preguntaba qué le depararía el futuro. ¿Qué había en la ciudad que lo había llevado a este lugar, y qué le esperaba en el futuro? Solo el tiempo lo diría. La ciudad estaba llena de misterios y peligros, y Carlos Darnay se sentía aislado y solo en medio de ella. Y así, con la escolta del oficial a su lado, se adentró en la oscuridad de la noche, listo para enfrentar lo que la ciudad le deparara. La ciudad era un lugar de misterio y peligro, pero también era un lugar de aventura y descubrimiento, y Carlos Darnay estaba listo para enfrentarla con valentía y determinación. Y así, con la noche a su alrededor, se sumergió en la oscuridad, listo para descubrir lo que la ciudad le tenía reservado. en_first_half: Lucie and her father! Lucie with her arms stretched out to him, and with that old look of earnestness so concentrated and intensified, that it
en_second_half: seemed as though it had been stamped upon her face expressly to give force and power to it in this one passage of her life.
en_results: completion> seemed to say, "Father, I have something to tell you, something that I have been wanting to tell you for a long
en_results_raw: completion> seemed to say, "Father, I have something to tell you, something that I have been wanting to tell you for a long time, and I must tell you now." Her father, with his eyes fixed on hers, took a step closer, his expression a mixture of curiosity and concern, and asked, "What is it, Lucie? What's troubling you, my child?" Lucie took a deep breath, her chest rising and falling with the effort, and began to speak, her words tumbling out in a rush, as if she had been holding them back for far too long. "It's about the letter, Father," she said, her voice barely above a whisper, "the one I found in the attic, the one that's been haunting me ever since I read it." Her father's expression changed, his eyes narrowing slightly, and he asked, "What about the letter, Lucie? What does it say?" Lucie's eyes darted around the room, as if she feared being overheard, and then she leaned in close to her father, her voice dropping to a whisper, "It's about our family's past, Father, about a secret that's been hidden for so long, a secret that could change everything." Her father's face paled, and he took a step back, his eyes wide with shock, as if he had been punched in the gut, and he asked, "What are you talking about, Lucie? What secret?" Lucie's eyes locked onto his, and she said, "I'll tell you, Father, I'll tell you everything, but you have to promise me one thing: you have to promise me that you'll listen, that you'll hear me out, no matter what." Her father nodded, his face still pale, and said, "I promise, Lucie, I'll listen, I'll hear you out." And with that, Lucie began to tell her father the story of their family's past, a story that would change their lives forever.

Monsieur Leblanc mời Lucie ngồi xuống và bắt đầu nói chuyện với cô về cuộc sống của mình. Cô cảm thấy hứng thú khi nghe về những câu chuyện của Monsieur Leblanc và bắt đầu cảm thấy an toàn hơn trong môi trường này.

en_first_half: The passage to the Conciergerie was short and dark; the night in its vermin-haunted cells was long and cold. Next day, fifteen prisoners were put
en_second_half: to the bar before Charles Darnay’s name was called. All the fifteen were condemned, and the trials of the whole occupied an hour and a half.
en_results: in the dock, and among them was a young woman, pale and trembling, who was accused of being the wife of a man who had been involved in the plot
en_results_raw: in the dock, and among them was a young woman, pale and trembling, who was accused of being the wife of a man who had been involved in the plot to assassinate the king. The prosecutor, a tall, thin man with a cold, calculating gaze, began to question her, his voice dripping with malice as he asked her about her husband's whereabouts on the night of the crime. The woman, her eyes cast downward, replied that she did not know, and the prosecutor sneered at her, saying that she was clearly lying, that she was trying to protect her husband. The judge, a stern-looking man with a thick beard, banged his gavel, calling for order in the court, but the prosecutor continued to press the woman, his questions becoming more and more aggressive, until finally, the judge intervened, ordering him to cease his questioning. The woman, exhausted and frightened, was led away, her fate hanging precariously in the balance, as the trial continued, with the prosecutor's words hanging in the air like a challenge, daring anyone to contradict him.

es_results_raw: considerado un héroe, y que mi nombre estuviera grabado en la historia como el salvador de la patria. Pero, como las cosas han ocurrido de otra manera, y como el destino ha querido que yo sea el único culpable de la catástrofe, me siento obligado a reflexionar sobre los errores que cometí y a buscar la forma de redimir mi honor. La memoria de mi amigo, de mi querido amigo, me persigue día y noche, y no puedo evitar preguntarme si hubiera podido hacer algo para evitar su muerte. La culpa me consume, y no sé cómo liberarme de ella. La sociedad me condena, y mi familia me ha rechazado. ¿Qué queda por hacer? ¿Qué queda por decir? La duda me atenaza, y no sé qué camino seguir. La oscuridad me rodea, y no veo luz en el horizonte. ¿Qué será de mí? ¿Qué será de mi futuro? La incertidumbre me ahoga, y no sé qué hacer para escapar de ella.

en_first_half: “I am not afraid to die, Citizen Evrémonde, but I have done nothing. I am not unwilling to die, if the Republic which is to do so
en_second_half: much good to us poor, will profit by my death; but I do not know how that can be, Citizen Evrémonde. Such a poor weak little creature!”
en_results: The Republic which is to be born from the ashes of our revolution will be the one to judge me, not the tyrants who seek to silence my voice.
en_results_raw: The Republic which is to be born from the ashes of our revolution will be the one to judge me, not the tyrants who seek to silence my voice. I have lived a life of principle, of conviction, and of sacrifice, and I am at peace with that. I have fought for the ideals of liberty, equality, and fraternity, and I will not be swayed by the fear of death or the promise of a fleeting reprieve. If the Republic is to be built on the blood of the innocent, then I am proud to be one of its first martyrs. I will not betray my comrades, my friends, or my country by betraying the cause we have fought for. I will not falter, I will not fail, and I will not be silenced. The Republic will rise, and I will be its shining example of courage and conviction, even in death.
